comments.content:
"Technical Requirements - Ensure that the projects in Azure DevOps can be accessed from the corporate network only."

Conditional access

Conditional access is fine.
WIP is applied after the user already made the connection for blocking information sharing.
The question is to not even make the connection - so Conditional access

discussion.content:
This is wrong, conditional access only dictates access to an app, but does not protect the sharing of App DATA such as coping code - that is Windows Information Protection. See below link.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/information-protection/windows-information-protection/protect-enterprise-data-using-wip

key quotes are
"For example, if WIP management is set to Block, your employees can copy and paste from one protected app to another protected app, but not to personal apps."

"WIP lets you block, allow overrides, or audit employees' data sharing actions. Hiding overrides stops the action immediately. Allowing overrides lets the employee know there's a risk, but lets him or her continue to share the data while recording and auditing the action. "

Therefore, since the question is asking to prevent the sharing of proprietary code. We're not restricting who has ACCESS to that data, but restricting how someone with access can SHARE that data.

Final answer. B - Windows Information Protection (WIP)

comments.content: Considering the overall situation WIP would be better suited but agreed - both can be possibilities.

discussion.content: Wip and conditional access both sound like possibilities
Tricky question, we don't which version already installed....

For Windows 10 hybrid Azure AD join, the minimum domain controller version is Windows Server 2008 R2, so there's no need to upgrade domain controllers or domain functional levels.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/hybrid-azuread-join-plan

Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) is not mentioned in the requirement as Schra mentioned. The possible answer is Microsoft Endpoint Configuration Manager.
Correct

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/configmgr/comanage/overview#windows
Co-management has these prerequisites in the following areas:
Licensing
Configuration Manager
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD)
Microsoft Intune
Windows
Permissions and roles

- Co-management requires Configuration Manager version 1710 or later
- Windows 10, version 1709 or later
- no specific domain controller or level requirement specified
so the answer must be correct
